pt: {sc}inconstant{/sc} {sc}fickle{/sc} {sc}capricious{/sc} {sc}mercurial{/sc} {sc}unstable{/sc} mean lacking firmness or steadiness (as in purpose or devotion). {sc}inconstant{/sc} implies an incapacity for steadiness and an inherent tendency to change.
{sc}fickle{/sc} suggests unreliability because of perverse changeability and incapacity for steadfastness.

pt.t: performers discover how {it}fickle{/it} fans can be

pt: {sc}capricious{/sc} suggests motivation by sudden whim or fancy and stresses unpredictability.
{sc}mercurial{/sc} implies a rapid changeability in mood.

pt.t: made anxious by her boss's {it}mercurial{/it} temperament

pt: {sc}unstable{/sc} implies an incapacity for remaining in a fixed position or steady course and applies especially to a lack of emotional balance.

quotes.t: Still grinning, still miming, he samba-ed across the floor … and started in on the dishes with a vigor that would have prostrated his {qword}mercurial{/qword} cousin.

Some scientists suggest that because manic-depressive patients are ever riding the bio-chemical express between emotional extremes, their brains end up more complexly wired and remain more persistently plastic than do the brains of less {qword}mercurial{/qword} sorts.

Though you could see all three places in one day, each of them makes you want to stay or to keep returning to watch the effects of the changing weather and the {qword}mercurial{/qword} Sicilian light.
Few moments in English history have been more hungry for the future, its {qword}mercurial{/qword} possibilities and its hope of richness, than the spring of 1603.
